misconceptions.name: Implemented a different problem instead of the requested grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points instead of a grade-to-letter-grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade and maps it to A/B/C/D/F.
misconceptions.student_belief: For this question, I just need to write any correct Java program (here, computing the distance between two points), rather than specifically implementing the numeric grade to letter grade mapping described.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must match the problem specification: read one numeric grade between 0 and 100 from the user and use conditional logic to print the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the given ranges. Any other behavior, even if the code is syntactically correct and solves a different problem, does not satisfy the requirements.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade.
Program never reads a grade or any value in the 0–100 range as a grade.
No conditional (if/else) logic to check grade ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.).
Output reports a numeric distance instead of a letter grade.
No output in the form 'Letter grade: X'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different textbook or homework problems (e.g., reusing a solution for 'distance between two points') or not carefully reading the current question’s specification. The student may focus on writing any working program rather than aligning the logic and I/O with the exact requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement slowly and highlight the key requirements: (1) read one numeric grade (0–100); (2) use if/else-if/else to check which interval the grade falls in; (3) print the corresponding letter. Start by changing the prompts and variables to represent a single grade, then add conditional checks for A, B, C, D, and F. Finally, test with sample inputs like 95, 85, 75, 65, and 50 to verify the outputs.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categorical values
Designing input and output to match a spec
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted program solves a completely different textbook-style problem (distance between points) and does not attempt any of the grade-calculation behavior (single grade input, conditional ranges, letter outputs). This strongly suggests misunderstanding of the question or reusing the wrong solution file, but there is a small chance it was an accidental mis-upload rather than a conceptual misunderstanding.

evidence.note: The program reads four doubles representing coordinates and computes a distance, with no reading of a single grade or conditional mapping to a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Assignment Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a complete and functional program for calculating the distance between two Cartesian points, which is a different problem than the required Grade Calculator task (Q3).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the submitted code fulfills the requirements of Q3, or they confused the requirements for Q3 with another assignment/problem (Distance Formula calculation).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The correct solution must read a single numeric grade (0-100) and utilize conditional statements (if/else-if) to output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Program calculates Euclidean distance
Reads four double inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one numeric grade
The output is a floating-point distance, not a letter grade
The class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints'
misconceptions.root_cause: Submitting the wrong file, misreading the assignment prompt, or coding a solution for a previous or unrelated exercise instead of the current one.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please carefully check the assignment prompt (Q3: Grade Calculator) and ensure the correct code that implements conditional logic for grade determination is submitted.
related_concepts: Input handling (matching input type to problem requirement)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is an entirely different program (Distance Calculator) than the required assignment (Grade Calculator).

evidence.note: The class and file name indicate a 'Distance between Points' program, not a 'Grade Calculator'.
The program prompts for and reads four coordinate variables, demonstrating input handling completely unrelated to reading a single student grade.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %f%n", Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: The program calculates and prints Euclidean distance, indicating no attempt was made to implement the required conditional logic for grade calculation.

misconceptions.name: Complete task misalignment - solving wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student wrote code to calculate the distance between two points in 2D space, when the assignment explicitly asked for a grade calculator that reads a numeric grade (0-100) and outputs a letter grade (A-F).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should solve a distance calculation problem rather than a grade conversion problem, or did not read/understand the problem specification.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read a single numeric grade value (0-100) and output the corresponding letter grade based on the specified scale (A: 90-100, B: 80-89, C: 70-79, D: 60-69, F: <60). The solution requires conditional logic (if/else or switch) to map ranges to letter grades.
symptoms: Program reads four double values instead of one numeric grade
Program calculates distance using Math.pow and Math.sqrt instead of comparing grade ranges
Output is a floating-point distance value, not a letter grade
No conditional logic (if/else) to map grade ranges to letters
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either did not carefully read the problem specification, copied code from a different assignment, or misunderstood what was being asked. The class name 'DistanceBetweenPoints' suggests this code was written for a different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over: (1) Use Scanner to read one integer or double representing the grade; (2) Use if/else or switch statements to check which range the grade falls into; (3) Output the corresponding letter grade. Example: if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } etc.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves a completely different problem. It reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates and calculates Euclidean distance. The problem statement and sample run clearly show a grade calculator is required. This is not ambiguous.

evidence.note: Entire program solves distance calculation instead of grade conversion. Reads 4 coordinate values and outputs distance, not the single grade input and letter grade output specified in the problem.
Class name indicates this is code from a different problem (distance between points), not a grade calculator.

misconceptions.name: Failure to address the assigned problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for calculating the distance between two points (a likely previous or unrelated problem) instead of the required grade calculator program. This reflects a fundamental failure to follow instructions or properly manage files/tasks.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either mistook the current assignment for a previous one, or they submitted the wrong file entirely. They did not attempt to implement the logic for the grade calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task required implementing a grade calculator using conditional logic (if/else if/else) based on a single numeric input (0-100).
symptoms: Code implements coordinate input and distance calculation
Required grading logic (if/else structure) is completely absent
Class name ('DistanceBetweenPoints') does not match the problem ('Grade Calculator')
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the current required task, file management error (submitting the wrong file), or failing to read the assignment prompt.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always double-check that the program being developed and submitted directly addresses the learning objectives and requirements of the current assignment (Q3: Grade Calculator). Review the specific problem prompt before writing any code.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code provided solves an entirely different introductory programming problem (distance formula) than the one assigned (grade calculator).

evidence.note: The class name suggests an unrelated purpose.
The entire main logic focuses on reading four coordinate inputs and calculating distance, rather than reading one grade and applying conditional logic.

misconceptions.name: Task/Problem Mismatch - Wrong Program Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a program that solves a completely different problem (distance between two points) instead of the assigned grade calculator task. The code reads coordinates and calculates Euclidean distance, with no grade classification logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either believes this distance calculation program is the solution to the grade calculator problem, or submitted the wrong file entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The grade calculator program should read a single numeric grade (0-100), evaluate it against five ranges (A/B/C/D/F), and output the corresponding letter grade. It should NOT involve coordinate inputs or distance calculations.
symptoms: Program requests 'Enter x1 and y1' instead of 'Enter grade'
Uses Math.pow() and Math.sqrt() for distance formula instead of if-else for grade ranges
Outputs a floating-point distance instead of a letter grade
Sample run would be completely wrong (entering 85 would ask for y1, y2 instead of outputting B)
misconceptions.root_cause: Either accidental submission of wrong file, or fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements. This suggests the student may not have carefully read and understood the problem specification before coding.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. Write code to read a SINGLE grade value. Use if-else statements to check ranges: if (grade >= 90) output A, else if (grade >= 80) output B, etc. Test with the sample input (85 should output B).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The mismatch is absolute and unambiguous. The submitted code solves a different problem entirely with completely different inputs, logic, and outputs. There is no overlap between distance calculation and grade classification.

evidence.note: Entire program incorrectly solves distance-between-points problem instead of grade calculator. Wrong class name, wrong inputs, wrong algorithm, wrong output.
Requests coordinate inputs instead of grade input

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %f%n", Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: Calculates and outputs Euclidean distance instead of letter grade
